reason: Review existing Jesse person doc before appending new info from this sync.

data.body:
## Role
- CTO at LoopWork

## Location
- Berkeley, CA

## Profiles
- GitHub: @anotherjesse

## Background
- Built OpenStack at NASA (helped start the project and built the team).
- Planet.com: SVP Product/Engineering; scaled team to ~75; later Fellow.
- Deep AI experience (2018–2021): embeddings, autoencoders.
- Created userscripts.org; built multiple large open-source projects.

## Notable beliefs / insights
- Belief that LLMs can bridge communication gaps between disciplines (e.g., legal, product, engineering, marketing).
- Early LLM conviction influenced by Riley Goodside’s GPT-3 graphviz demo.
## Updates from Sparks source (2025-01-23)
- Sparks is described as Jesse’s **first Rust project** (quote: “if it compiles, it works”).
- Frames Sparks as “agentic-first cloud compute,” drawing an analogy to OpenStack’s enabling of new capabilities beyond cost savings (scale to thousands, back to zero; shift time/space).

## Notes
These items are beliefs/framings associated with Jesse in the Sparks design doc; they may also represent a broader team narrative, but are attributed to “Jesse” in the source text.

tool_args.reason: Check existing Sparks project framing; this doc adds definition of 'Spark native app'.

reason: Check existing Sparks project framing; this doc adds definition of 'Spark native app'.

data.body:
## Summary
Sparks provides instant sandbox environments (“sparks”) in isolated containers with **persistent filesystems** backed by **btrfs snapshots**. It is a CLI tool intended to be fast and composable.

- Repo: https://github.com/loopwork/sparks
- Local path (as noted in source): `~/lw/sparks`
- Language: Rust
- Lineage: spiritual child of **Vibewire** (monolithic Elixir system)

## Philosophy
- Simple CLI that does one thing well (avoid all-in-one systems).
- Coding agents own code + tests.
- Humans own verification flow (automated QA / smoke tests).
- Treat agent output like outsourced dev: passing tests ≠ “right for you.”

## Core features / commands
- Lifecycle: `spark create`, `delete`, `stop`, `resume`
- Execution: `spark exec`, `spark console`
- Snapshots: `spark snapshot create`, `restore` (btrfs)
- Templates: `spark base` (save a spark as a template)
- Persistent volumes: `spark data` (share data across sparks)
- Secrets: `spark secrets` (1Password integration)
- Namespacing: “Projects” for namespace isolation; auto-detect from git repo
- Ephemeral sparks: `-` creates an auto-deleting spark on exit

## System volumes (auto-mounted)
- `/spark/bin` — shared executables (global)
- `/spark/all` — shared data (global)
- `/spark/proj` — shared data (per project)

## Vision
Positioned as “agentic-first cloud compute” (analogous to OpenStack for VMs): infrastructure that enables new “physics” for agentic workloads, including fast scale up/down and time/space shifting of computation.

Key exploration: frozen agent-built artifacts feel “dead,” so Sparks aims toward continuously agentic execution where boundaries blur between dev iteration and shipped product, static apps vs. just-in-time interfaces, and human collaboration vs. agent-mediated communication.

## Validated capability
- 2025-01-24: **Hard snapshots work with stateful apps**—Postgres survives unannounced btrfs snapshots via WAL crash recovery; suggests “fork anything anytime” can be real.

## Status (as of week of 2025-01-23)
Working toward Sparks being able to “develop itself” by moving development “onto the inside,” refining git workflows and trust boundaries between source vs. data, and building composable primitives (“LEGOs”).


## Priorities and near-term work (from CTO priorities, 2025-01-23)
- **Self-hosting development** remains the top goal: get Sparks to a point where it can develop itself (trust boundaries; git workflows; source vs data separation; composable "LEGOs").
- **spark-pg service** (working as of 2025-01-25):
  - Commands implemented: `spark-pg new`, `fork`, `connect`, `status`.
  - Uses `spark-client` crate directly.
  - Establishes a pattern for additional "service" wrappers (e.g., redis).
  - Open question: how much service complexity should live **inside Spark** vs **outside** as separate services.
- **Dev Spark containers with KVM**: priority item to improve local/dev parity.
- **Dev/Prod unification (blocking)**: currently divergent scripts/flows/settings; target is one path with flag differences, affecting deploy/setup/verify.
- Ops/dev UX notes:
  - SSH multi-connection + SFTP reportedly working with tests passing (2025-01-25).
  - Zed terminal "spins on connect" issue is likely not Sparks-specific.

reason: Check existing LoopWork project doc; this sync includes priorities and initiatives (skills repo, Loop chat, cl_draw).

data.body:
## Snapshot
- Stage: pre-product; exploring product–market fit.
- Runway: ~$2M cash.
- Focus (Q1 2025): “Cursor/Claude Code for media” — AI-assisted creative tools.
- Initial modality: images (Q1 2025), with interest in video next.

## Team
- CEO: Carl Peaslee (SF; GitHub @carlpeaslee)
- CTO: Jesse Andrews (Berkeley; GitHub @anotherjesse)

## Status (as of 2025-01-23)
- Funding/runway: ✅
- Product defined: ❌ (direction under exploration)
- MVP built: ❌
- First users: ❌
- Revenue / market awareness: ❌

## Strategy under consideration
1. Product path: build toward revenue.
2. Awareness path: build reputation with an eye toward acquihire.

## Notes
The company previously explored a dev-tools concept (Vibewire) but pivoted away from dev tools due to perceived oversaturation and major investment by large model companies.


## Priorities (from CTO priorities, 2025-01-23)
- **Internal tooling** is a top-3 focus:
  - Replace iMessage with an internal chat tool: **Loop chat** (intended as the first Spark-native app).
  - Support voice call/session logging (noted with Carl).
  - Create a shared skills repository at **`loop.work/skills`**.
  - **Conversation recording for AI context**: record Claude Code sessions, chats, and calls so future AI systems can browse organizational history when needed.
- **Agentic imagery exploration** is an active direction: interpret and prototype what a "Cursor for images" could be; Q1 focus images, then video.

## Strategy note
Reiterates two strategic options given ~$2M runway: (1) build toward product/revenue; (2) build awareness/reputation with potential acquihire in mind.

data.body:
## Summary
`spark-pg` is a Sparks-adjacent service/CLI for managing Postgres databases in the Sparks ecosystem.

## Status
- Working as of **2025-01-25**.

## Implemented commands
- `spark-pg new`
- `spark-pg fork`
- `spark-pg connect`
- `spark-pg status`

## Implementation notes
- Uses the `spark-client` crate directly.
- Intended to establish a repeatable pattern for additional services (e.g., `spark-redis`).

## Open question
- Architectural boundary: how much complexity should live **inside Spark** vs. **outside** Spark in separate services.

tool_args.reason: See if shared skills repository concept overlaps with existing skills/tooling docs.

reason: See if shared skills repository concept overlaps with existing skills/tooling docs.

data.body:
## Tools

- Tools are defined with **TypeBox** schemas (`@sinclair/typebox`) to provide typed parameter definitions with runtime validation.
- Schema guardrails mentioned:
  - Avoid `Type.Union` (i.e., avoid `anyOf`/`oneOf`/`allOf`).
  - Prefer `Type.Optional()` instead of `| null`.
  - Keep the top-level schema as `type: "object"` with `properties`.

## Skills

- Skills are higher-level capabilities defined in `SKILL.md` files with YAML frontmatter (e.g., `name`, `description`, and metadata such as required binaries or environment variables).
- **Precedence hierarchy**: workspace skills override managed skills, which override bundled skills.
- **Load-time gating** filters skills based on required:
  - binaries
  - environment variables
  - config paths
  - OS platform

## Tool availability controls

- Tools can be allow/deny listed per agent.
- Profile presets are mentioned: `minimal`, `coding`, `messaging`, `full`.
- Tool groups provide shorthands, e.g.:
  - `group:fs` (file ops)
  - `group:runtime` (exec/process)
  - `group:web` (search/fetch)

tool_args.author: ingest-agent

patch.body_append:
## Summary
This sync captures a set of immediate infrastructure/developer-experience blockers (primarily affecting Carl) and several architectural/product decisions for LoopWork’s “Spark native” app ecosystem.

**Jesse’s immediate priorities** were framed as pragmatic unblockers:
- **tmux terminal sizing in SSH sessions** (Carl’s #1 blocker): tmux not going full-screen; `Ctrl+L` then `reset` is a temporary workaround; blocks effective vim/ncurses workflows.
- **Postgres patterns** (timeboxed ~1 hour): establish a simple model for **persistent Postgres instances** (production) plus **throwaway/ephemeral instances** for testing/verification, and workable **backup + fork** flows for staging; `test_postgres.sh` exists as a reference.
- **SSH improvements**: current limitation of one connection per node; **SCP/SFTP not working** (blocks Zed integration); Zed “Z-links” for remote editing failing.
- **Dev Spark containers with KVM**: run Kate inside a container with networking; only needs to work from the dev node.

**Carl’s focus areas**: (1) Picnic development using latest Spark best practices; (2) Loop chat (positioned as the first Spark-native app); (3) deployment and improvements to **cl_draw**.

**Decisions/architecture patterns**:
- Create a **shared skills repository** at `loop.work/skills` to consolidate scattered skill definitions; begin with manual sync and evolve to a CLI; structure includes a skills directory with symlinks to Claude/agents.
- Maintain **separation between external vs. internal tooling**: Picnic requires standalone external capabilities; internal tools can reuse underlying skills, but avoid tight coupling that blocks external use.
- Adopt a **CLI-first pattern**: cl_draw as a CLI canvas-manipulation + AI illustration tool; potential `docs.loop.work` with a Prosemirror editor; chat UI backed by a CLI backend.

**Operational gap identified**: a recurring deployment issue around **port 8080** indicates missing standardized HTTP service patterns across projects.

**Key insight**: “Spark native app” means an agentic computing framework built on Spark; being Spark-native does **not** imply coupling to internal systems.

## Stated next steps
- Jesse: fix tmux sizing issue; implement Postgres patterns.
- Carl: continue Picnic with latest Spark practices; deploy cl_draw and explore web-first over Atari automation.
- Both: establish the shared skills repository workflow.

## Notes
- Jesse can kill Carl’s SSH sessions while deploying fixes.
- Carl is not using Claude outside tmux in sensitive ways.
patch.title: Carl Sync — 2025-01-23 (source summary)

patch.body_append:
## Immediate priorities (2025-01-23 sync)
- Fix **tmux sizing issue** in SSH sessions (Carl’s #1 blocker; `Ctrl+L` then `reset` is a temporary fix).
- Implement simple **Postgres patterns**: persistent instances for prod; ephemeral/throwaway instances for tests/verification; backup + fork workflow for staging (reference: `test_postgres.sh`).
- Improve SSH ergonomics: enable multiple connections per node; restore **SCP/SFTP** (blocks Zed integration); fix Zed remote-edit links.
- Enable dev Spark containers with **KVM**: run Kate inside container with networking (only required from dev node).

tool_args.author: ingest-agent

patch.body_append:
## Summary
Picnic is a LoopWork application under development intended to follow the latest Spark/Sparks best practices. A key architectural requirement is that Picnic must have **standalone external capabilities** (not tightly coupled to internal-only systems), even if internal tools share underlying skills.

## Notes (2025-01-23 sync)
- Treated as a **Spark-native** app, where “Spark native” denotes an agentic computing framework built on Spark/Sparks rather than coupling to internal infrastructure.
- Explicit decision: keep **external vs. internal tool separation** so external use cases are not blocked by internal dependencies.

## Status
- Active development as of 2025-01-23.
patch.title: Picnic

tool_args.reason: Create a project doc for Picnic, referenced as a major development focus and requiring external capabilities separation.

patch.body_append:
## Summary
cl_draw is a LoopWork project focused on **canvas manipulation** and **AI-assisted illustration**, with an explicit **CLI-first** product pattern. It is also an active deployment target.

## Notes (2025-01-23 sync)
- CLI-first: cl_draw as the backend/primitive; other interfaces (chat/web) may layer on top.
- Carl focus: deploy cl_draw and explore **web-first** approaches over Atari-style automation.

## Status
- Active work and deployment improvements as of 2025-01-23.
patch.title: cl_draw

tool_args.reason: Create a project doc for cl_draw, referenced with CLI-first canvas/illustration pattern and deployment focus.

reason: Create a project doc for cl_draw, referenced with CLI-first canvas/illustration pattern and deployment focus.

tool_args.author: ingest-agent

patch.body_append:
## Summary
Loop chat is an internal chat application at LoopWork, intended to replace iMessage and described as the **first Spark-native app**.

## Notes (2025-01-23 sync)
- Part of the push to build Spark-native internal tools while maintaining clean separation from externally usable tooling.

## Status
- Under active development/planning as of 2025-01-23.
patch.title: Loop chat

tool_args.reason: Create a project doc for Loop chat, described as the first Spark-native app (internal chat replacement).

reason: Create a project doc for Loop chat, described as the first Spark-native app (internal chat replacement).

tool_args.author: ingest-agent

patch.body_append:
## Decision
Create a shared repository at **`loop.work/skills`** to consolidate skill definitions that were previously scattered.

## Intended workflow
- Start with **manual sync** of skills; introduce a dedicated **CLI tool later**.
- Maintain a **skills directory** and use **symlinks** to connect skills into Claude/agent environments.
patch.title: Shared skills repository (loop.work/skills)

tool_args.reason: Create a system fact capturing the decision to create a shared skills repository at loop.work/skills and how it will be organized/synced.

reason: Create a system fact capturing the decision to create a shared skills repository at loop.work/skills and how it will be organized/synced.

tool_args.author: ingest-agent

patch.body_append:
## Definition / principle
Within LoopWork, a **“Spark native app”** is an application built as an **agentic computing framework on Spark/Sparks**.

Critically, being Spark-native does **not** mean the app is coupled to internal-only systems.

## Implications
- Maintain **external vs. internal tool separation**:
  - External-facing apps (e.g., Picnic) must have standalone capabilities.
  - Internal tools may reuse the same underlying skills, but should avoid tight coupling that blocks external use cases.
patch.title: Spark-native apps: agentic on Spark, not coupled to internal systems

tool_args.reason: Record the architectural principle that 'Spark native' should not imply tight coupling to internal systems; include external/internal tool separation.

reason: Record the architectural principle that 'Spark native' should not imply tight coupling to internal systems; include external/internal tool separation.

tool_args.author: ingest-agent

patch.body_append:
## Problem
A recurring deployment issue across projects relates to **port 8080**, indicating a lack of standardized/documented patterns for running and deploying HTTP services.

## Need
- Establish a **standard HTTP service pattern** (ports, env/config, reverse proxy/ingress assumptions, and deploy checklist) so projects don’t repeatedly hit the same 8080-related trap.
patch.title: HTTP services: recurring port 8080 deployment/documentation gap

tool_args.reason: Capture the recurring deployment issue around port 8080 as a system fact indicating a documentation/pattern gap for HTTP services.

reason: Capture the recurring deployment issue around port 8080 as a system fact indicating a documentation/pattern gap for HTTP services.

content:
Ingested **2025-01-23-carl-sync** (Source ID: `src_01KGAMF16BHX3QRAJSV7DV8F6K`) and updated the knowledge base after searching for existing related docs to avoid duplicates.

## Written / updated docs

### Source summary
- `summaries/sources/2025-01-23-carl-sync.md`  
  Captures: Jesse’s immediate priorities (tmux sizing, Postgres patterns, SSH improvements, KVM dev containers), Carl’s focus (Picnic, Loop chat, cl_draw), decisions (shared skills repo, external/internal separation, CLI-first), port 8080 deployment doc gap, and next steps.

### People (updated)
- `knowledge/people/carl-peaslee.md`  
  Appended Carl’s current focus and his tmux sizing blocker.
- `knowledge/people/jesse-andrews.md`  
  Appended Jesse’s immediate priority list from this sync.

### Projects (created)
- `knowledge/projects/picnic.md`
- `knowledge/projects/cl_draw.md`
- `knowledge/projects/loop-chat.md`

### System facts / principles (created)
- `knowledge/system/shared-skills-repo-loopwork.md` (decision/workflow for `loop.work/skills`)
- `knowledge/system/spark-native-not-internal-coupling.md` (definition/principle of “Spark native app” ≠ internal coupling)
- `knowledge/system/http-service-port-8080-pattern-gap.md` (recurring port 8080 deployment/documentation gap)

No preference docs were created from this source (it primarily contained priorities, decisions, and system gaps).
